messages.text: I want to pass a function as an argument to another function to fit a curve.  The function passed as an argument is the curve equation, and the function to which it is passed fits it to an array of data also passed as an argument to the curve-fitting function.  What is the syntax for passing the curve equation to the curve-fitting function?

elements.text: I want to pass a function as an argument to another function to fit a curve.  The function passed as an argument is the curve equation, and the function to which it is passed fits it to an array of data also passed as an argument to the curve-fitting function.  What is the syntax for passing the curve equation to the curve-fitting function?

messages.text:
Here’s how I imagine it would work:

```curve(x) = ...

curve_fit(data, curve) = ...

data = [...]
curve_fit(data, curve)
```

elements.text: Here’s how I imagine it would work:

curve(x) = ...

curve_fit(
data,
curve) = ...
data = [...]
curve_fit(
data,
curve)

messages.text: Yes that is right

elements.text: Yes that is right

messages.text: Though convention is if your argument is a function it should be the first argument

elements.text: Though convention is if your argument is a function it should be the first argument

messages.text: But still works in any position. Just won't be able to use `do` block form

do
block form

messages.text: Ok, now suppose that curve(x) were curve(a,x), where a is not defined within the scope of curve_fit(curve, data).  If I defined a outside the scope, would that ‘just work’?

elements.text: Ok, now suppose that curve(x) were curve(a,x), where a is not defined within the scope of curve_fit(curve, data).  If I defined a outside the scope, would that ‘just work’?

messages.text: Yes.

elements.text: Yes.

messages.text:
```curve_fit(curve, data) = ...

a = ...
curve(a,x) = ...
data = [...]
curve_fit(curve, data)```

elements.text: curve_fit(curve, data) = ...
curve(a,x) = ...
data = [...]
curve_fit(curve, data)

messages.text: Like this?

elements.text: Like this?

messages.text: Yes

elements.text: Yes

messages.text: Wooooo! :D  Hooray for generic programming!

elements.text: Wooooo! :D  Hooray for generic programming!

messages.text:
I think something might be being missed here
The `a` in  `a = ...` 
And the `a` in `curve(a, x)` are not at all linked to each other.
Those are different variables.
If you then did a call say `y = curve(a, data[:, 1])`
Then within that call they are the same variable.

elements.text:
I think something might be being missed here
The
a
in
And the
a
in
curve(a, x)

are not at all linked to each other.
Those are different variables.
If you then did a call say
y = curve(a, data[:, 1])
Then within that call they are the same variable.

messages.text:
```curve_fit = (curve, data)
curve(a, x) = ...
a = ...
data = [...]
y = curve(a, data[:,1])
curve_fit(y, data)```

elements.text: curve_fit = (curve, data)
curve(a, x) = ...
data = [...]
y = curve(a, data[:,1])
curve_fit(y, data)

messages.text:
Are you looking to take a function `foo(a, x)` and turn it onto a function only of `x`? by subsituting `a=a0`? (also called partial evaluation)
that is done via creating a closure over `a0`
`foo_partial(x) = foo(a0, x)`
(or you could do it in anonymous function form:
`x->foo(a0, x)`

messages.text:
```The number of product molecules of a chemical reaction whereby two reagent particles fuse into a single product molecule can be predicted by the following function of time

product_equation(a, b, t) = b*(1 - 1/(a*t+1)^2)

where b is the maximum possible number of product molecules and a is constant to be determined by gradient descent curve-fitting.```

elements.text:

product_equation(a, b, t) = b*(1 - 1/(a*t+1)^2)

where b is the maximum possible number of product m
olecules
and a is constant to be determined by gradient descent curve-fitting.

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/SimonDeDeo|@SimonDeDeo>: OK julia FANS, what's up with *this*? It is *twenty times* slower than ruby in assigning a mixed-type array.

julia> a=time(); for i in 1:100000; b=[1,2.0]; end; time()-a
0.21590805053710938

irb> a=<http://Time.now>; 100000.times { b=[1,2.0] }; Time.now-a
=> 0.011791
attachments.text:
OK julia FANS, what's up with *this*? It is *twenty times* slower than ruby in assigning a mixed-type array.

julia> a=time(); for i in 1:100000; b=[1,2.0]; end; time()-a
0.21590805053710938

irb> a=<http://Time.now>; 100000.times { b=[1,2.0] }; Time.now-a
=> 0.011791

elements.text: The solution is to convert it to a union type, right?

messages.text: how does he do that? (PS this guy is evaluating  Julia, He's in the santa fe institute and could do a lot of cool things  with it)

elements.text: how does he do that? (PS this guy is evaluating  Julia, He's in the santa fe institute and could do a lot of cool things  with it)

messages.text:
<@U0168QX7E8N>
He is not timing the same thing in each language. In Julia, he is timing the promotion(Int, Float64) and the application of that result to type convert the entries of mixed type array into a promoted type array with the attendant allocations, and then the assignment of that.  In Ruby, I assume he his timing the assignment of a mixed type array. And always use `@time` or `@btime` from BenchmarkTools.jl.
```julia> bb = [1, 2.0] 
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.0
julia> bb = [Int(1), Float64(2)]
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.0
# this are timing promotions, allocations, and assignment
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=[1,2.0]; end
  0.150965 seconds (400.00 k allocations: 16.785 MiB)

# this are timing allocations, and assignment
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=[1.0,2.0]; end
  0.002405 seconds (100.00 k allocations: 9.155 MiB)

# this is timing assignment
julia>  bb = [1, 2.0];
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=bb; end
  0.000239 seconds # no allocations, this is assignment time```
The closest thing we have to that a preassigned array of Union type or  else a tuple of mixed types
```julia> bb=Union{Int,Float64}[1,2.0]
2-element Array{Union{Float64, Int64},1}:
 1
 2.0
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=bb; end
  0.000216 seconds

julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=(1,2.0); end
  0.000193 seconds

# so not 20 times slower than Ruby
julia> round(0.151 / 0.00785) 
20
# 20 times faster than the incorrectly determined 20 times slower

# or better yet, using Julia properly, much faster than Ruby
julia> round(0.151 / 0.00216) 
70```

elements.text: He is not timing the same thing in each language. In Ruby, I assume he his timing the assignment of a mixed type array. And always use `@time` or
@btime
from BenchmarkTools.jl.

julia> bb = [1, 2.0] 
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.0
julia> bb = [Int(1), Float64(2)]
2-element Array{Float64,1}:
 1.0
 2.0
# this are timing promotions, allocations, and assignment
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=[1,2.0]; end
  0.150965 seconds (400.00 k allocations: 16.785 MiB)

# this are timing allocations, and assignment
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=[1.0,2.0]; end
  0.002405 seconds (100.00 k allocations: 9.155 MiB)

# this is timing assignment
julia>  bb = [1, 2.0];
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=bb; end
  0.000239 seconds # no allocations, this is assignment time
The closest thing we have to that a preassigned array of Union type or  else a tuple of mixed types

julia> bb=Union{Int,Float64}[1,2.0]
2-element Array{Union{Float64, Int64},1}:
 1
 2.0
julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=bb; end
  0.000216 seconds

julia> @time for i in 1:100000; b=(1,2.0); end
  0.000193 seconds

# so not 20 times slower than Ruby
julia> round(0.151 / 0.00785) 
20
# 20 times faster than the incorrectly determined 20 times slower

# or better yet, using Julia properly, much faster than Ruby
julia> round(0.151 / 0.00216) 
70

messages.text:
I really like 1-based indexing, but there was this was one time when It forced my hand in a way I didn't appreciate: <https://github.com/JuliaIO/PNGFiles.jl/blob/master/src/io.jl#L211>
Paletted PNGs contain a vector of colors with up to 256 entries, the palette, and the image itself consists of indices to the palette -- so instead of 3 numbers for RGB, you can store just one UInt8 per pixel, yay! But If the palette contains 256 colors, and you use 1-based indexing, the largest index has value 256 which is not representable with UInt8.  So I had to switch to OffsetArrays for the pallet. Not a big deal, but it increased the complexity a little.

elements.text: I really like 1-based indexing, but there was this was one time when It forced my hand in a way I didn't appreciate:

Paletted PNGs contain a vector of colors with up to 256 entries, the palette, and the image itself consists of indices to the palette -- so instead of 3 numbers for RGB, you can store just one UInt8 per pixel, yay! But If the palette contains 256 colors, and you use 1-based indexing, the largest index has value 256 which is not representable with UInt8.  So I had to switch to OffsetArrays for the pallet. Not a big deal, but it increased the complexity a little.

messages.text: <@U68EM3QGP> <https://forums.swift.org/t/pitch-2-structured-concurrency/43452> - revised structured concurrency proposal

attachments.title: [Pitch #2] Structured Concurrency
attachments.text: Hi all, We've been revising the Structured Concurrency pitch document a bit to try to explain more about the design goals and fill in some gaps based on the discussion in the first pitch thread. Here's a list of the changes in this second pitch document: Added a "desugaring" of async let to task groups and more motivation for the structured-concurrency parts of the design. Reflowed the entire proposal to focus on the general description of structured concurrency first, the programming model w...

messages.text: Does anyone know if anything came out of the discussion on this discourse thread(<https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-get-commit-hash-in-pkg3/11927>)? I ran into the same thing recently where I was tracking a master branch and was trying to figure out where it was. It seemed like a good idea, but wasn't sure if it went anywhere.

attachments.title: How to get commit hash in Pkg3?
attachments.text: With the old package manager, I could go into the package directory and do a git status or something similar to find out which commit I was on. How do I do this with Pkg3? While ]st does print a hash next to each package, I can’t figure out what it is (it doesn’t appear to be the git commit hash). It does also print the package version/tag, but if the package is tracking master then I’m unable to actually figure out which commit its on. Thanks.

messages.text:
Is it correct to say that invalidations are  especially a problem for Base and Standard Libraries, due to extensive use of `precompile` and being in the system images?
Since for normal packages most code is loaded before it is used and thus compiled.
So while invalidations occur its much less of a problem in practice.
I didn’t spot anything explictly mentioning system image in <https://julialang.org/blog/2020/08/invalidations/>

messages.text: Hey, I come from Python, where actually using the language to do anything is discouraged, modules handle all the heavy lifting, and minimizing dependencies is important for interoperability.  I know that Julia was designed with the opposite intent but can’t shake the feeling that I should use packages, avoid objects, and keep my code in pure Julia for simplicity and performance.

messages.text:
so I've had a look through some LinearAlgebra code and came across the following in tridiag.jl:569:

```U = Array(Bidiagonal(getfield(getfield(F, :factors), :d), getfield(getfield(F, :factors), :du), d))```
Is there any specific reason it's written that way? or just leftover legacy code from 2014 (as far as I can tell)?

elements.text: so I've had a look through some LinearAlgebra code and came across the following in tridiag.jl:569:
U = Array(Bidiagonal(getfield(getfield(F, :factors), :d), getfield(getfield(F, :factors), :du), d))
Is there any specific reason it's written that way? or just leftover legacy code from 2014 (as far as I can tell)?

messages.text: e.g. `U = Array(Bidiagonal(F.factors.d, F.factors.du, d))` would work just the same, right?

elements.text: e.g.
U = Array(Bidiagonal(F.factors.d, F.factors.du, d))
would work just the same, right?

messages.text: Oh I'm silly, it's in a definition of `getproperty`

messages.text: Can someone explain to me what the role of the first `SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}[...` is in the expression `SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}[convert(SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}, (1/dx^derivative_order) * calculate_weights(derivative_order, oneunit(T)*x0, left_boundary_x)) for x0 in L_boundary_deriv_spots]`? For me it seems like it converts the arrays inside the list comprehension, so why does it need the SVector expresion on the outside as well?

elements.text: Can someone explain to me what the role of the first
SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}[...
is in the expression

SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}[convert(SVector{boundary_stencil_length, T}, (1/dx^derivative_order) * calculate_weights(derivative_order, oneunit(T)*x0, left_boundary_x)) for x0 in L_boundary_deriv_spots]
? For me it seems like it converts the arrays inside the list comprehension, so why does it need the SVector expresion on the outside as well?

messages.text: This may be naive but besides large executable sizes, can't Julia perform equally as well in the systems software realm as C and Rust if you disable GC and manage memory manually?

elements.text: This may be naive but besides large executable sizes, can't Julia perform equally as well in the systems software realm as C and Rust if you disable GC and manage memory manually?

messages.text: On a slightly related note, what if Julia had optional borrow checking for certain variables like rust? So GC would run regularly but for certain rust like variables, the memory could be cleaned up as soon as it goes out of scope. Is this even possible to do?

root.text: This may be naive but besides large executable sizes, can't Julia perform equally as well in the systems software realm as C and Rust if you disable GC and manage memory manually?

elements.text: This may be naive but besides large executable sizes, can't Julia perform equally as well in the systems software realm as C and Rust if you disable GC and manage memory manually?

On a slightly related note, what if Julia had optional borrow checking for certain variables like rust? So GC would run regularly but for certain rust like variables, the memory could be cleaned up as soon as it goes out of scope. Is this even possible to do?

messages.text: If Julia compiles to the LLVM, and static compilation, type checking, and manual memory management will soon be allowed, then what is the point of Rust?  A built-in linter could check, between statements guaranteeing that all the i’s have been dotted and t’s crossed within, and then do everything Rust does but with better semantics.

elements.text: If Julia compiles to the LLVM, and static compilation, type checking, and manual memory management will soon be allowed, then what is the point of Rust?  A built-in linter could check, between statements guaranteeing that all the i’s have been dotted and t’s crossed within, and then do everything Rust does but with better semantics.

messages.text: ^ Speaking of which, what's the current status on ahead-of-time compilation of Julia? Is it possible to take functions without dependencies on the Julia runtime, like `f(x::Int32) = 2*x + 1`, and compile them to a shared library (the equivalent of `extern 'C' int f(int x) { return 2*x + 1; }`)? I ask because I often use Julia's metaprogramming capabilities to generate code that evaluates special functions, and it's much more ergonomic to build Julia `Expr` trees than generate C source code

Expr

messages.text:
Hey, I discovered a strange behavior, which I didn't expect.
```julia> x = randn((2,2))
2×2 Array{Float64,2}:
  0.554563  -1.10587
 -1.39822    0.0850825

julia> x[1+1, 1]
-1.3982239652487247

julia> x[1 +1, 1]
ERROR: syntax: unexpected comma in matrix expression
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at none:1
 [2] run_repl(::REPL.AbstractREPL, ::Any) at /build/julia/src/julia-1.5.3/usr/share/julia/stdlib/v1.5/REPL/src/REPL.jl:288

julia> x[1 + 1, 1]
-1.3982239652487247```
It seems to originate from, which is reasonable because we can't distinguish it anymore. But in array indexing, this is somehow strange :cry:
```julia> [1 +1, 1]
ERROR: syntax: unexpected comma in matrix expression
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at none:1
 [2] run_repl(::REPL.AbstractREPL, ::Any) at /build/julia/src/julia-1.5.3/usr/share/julia/stdlib/v1.5/REPL/src/REPL.jl:288

julia> [1 +1 1]
^[OA1×3 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  1  1

julia> [1 + 1 1]
1×2 Array{Int64,2}:
 2  1```

messages.text:
I'm thinking of starting a project where I need to use a deep learning library. Not sure whether to do it in Python or Julia. Of course I prefer Julia, but I'm unsure about Julia's DL capabilities. How is Flux these days? Relatively stable and fast? Does it have GPU acceleration? I prefer "stable and reliable" over "have exciting new features for autodiff".
Edit: And is Flux still the go-to library?

attachments.title: New tools for reducing compiler latency
attachments.text: I’m pleased to announce the release of SnoopCompile 2.2.0, a major enhancement in the suite of tools for reducing “time to first plot.” This release provides considerably better insight into the costs of type inference, allowing you to profile the actions of inference in extensive detail. It also provides a new suite of tools for detecting and analyzing “inference triggers,” cases where a previously-uninferred method is called via runtime dispatch. As a quick visual for the new release, I’ll pa...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: New tools for reducing compiler latency

messages.text:
Hey everybody, I'd like to announce that I've just released *<https://github.com/dzhang314/MultiFloats.jl|MultiFloats.jl>*<https://github.com/dzhang314/MultiFloats.jl| >*<https://github.com/dzhang314/MultiFloats.jl|v1.0>*, my library for fast extended-precision arithmetic. It provides the types Float64x2, Float64x3, ..., Float64x8 for doing math with approximately 100, 150, ..., 400 accurate bits. It currently supports arithmetic (`+-*/`), `sqrt`, `exp`, and `log`. I'm still working on trig functions, but as a temporary workaround, you can call `MultiFloats.use_bigfloat_transcendentals()` to patch in BigFloat trig/hyperbolic functions for use with Float64xN.

Under the hood, a Float64xN is just an `NTuple{N,Float64}` manipulated using error-free transformations. The transformations we need in order to go up to Float64x8 are too large to practically write by hand, so they are generated with metaprogramming at library load time. I've taken care to ensure that the generated code compiles down to a straight line of native, vectorizable Float64 operations, making *<https://github.com/dzhang314/MultiFloats.jl|MultiFloats.jl>* the fastest extended-precision library I know of in the 100-400 bit precision range.

A huge kudos to the Julia designers for providing this unique high-performance JIT architecture. I don't think a library like *<https://github.com/dzhang314/MultiFloats.jl|MultiFloats.jl>* could exist in any other language!

elements.text: Hey everybody, I'd like to announce that I've just released
MultiFloats.jl

, my library for fast extended-precision arithmetic. It provides the types Float64x2, Float64x3, ..., Float64x8 for doing math with approximately 100, 150, ..., 400 accurate bits. It currently supports arithmetic (
sqrt
exp
, and
log
. I'm still working on trig functions, but as a temporary workaround, you can call
MultiFloats.use_bigfloat_transcendentals()

to patch in BigFloat trig/hyperbolic functions for use with Float64xN.

Under the hood, a Float64xN is just an
NTuple{N,Float64}

manipulated using error-free transformations. The transformations we need in order to go up to Float64x8 are too large to practically write by hand, so they are generated with metaprogramming at library load time. I've taken care to ensure that the generated code compiles down to a straight line of native, vectorizable Float64 operations, making
MultiFloats.jl

the fastest extended-precision library I know of in the 100-400 bit precision range.

A huge kudos to the Julia designers for providing this unique high-performance JIT architecture. I don't think a library like
MultiFloats.jl
could exist in any other language!

<https://twitter.com/ChadScherrer|@ChadScherrer>: My book recommendations for #Bayesian analysis:

• Kevin Murphy: <https://probml.github.io/pml-book/book1.html>

• David MacKay: <http://www.inference.org.uk/mackay/itila/>

• David Barber: <http://web4.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/D.Barber/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Brml.Online>

• Chris Bishop: <https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/uploads/prod/2006/01/Bishop-Pattern-Recognition-and-Machine-Learning-2006.pdf>

All free online. Of course buy them if you can afford it :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: <https://users.rust-lang.org/t/exploring-rustffts-simd-architecture/53780>

attachments.title: Exploring RustFFT's SIMD Architecture
attachments.text: Exploring RustFFT's SIMD Architecture After Releasing RustFFT 5.0 yesterday, a few people asked for details on how RustFFT 5.0 achieved its speed improvements over RustFFT 4.0 and its newfound speed advantage over the C FFT library FFTW. In this post, I'll start by giving a high-level overview about FFT computation, then discuss how RustFFT computes FFTs, and finally dive into exactly how the AVX code is structured to maximize speed. FFT Overview The FFT is fundamentally a recursive process. N...
attachments.fallback: The Rust Programming Language Forum: Exploring RustFFT's SIMD Architecture

messages.text: <@USU9FRPEU> <@UH24GRBLL>

In order from left: Reagent Product Plot, Reagent Polynomial Regression, Product Polynomial Regression, Reagent Gradient Descent Curve Fit, Product Gradient Descent Curve Fit

The Polynomial Regressions were done with MLJ.jl, which I extended to allow arbitrary-term polynomial regressions rather than only linear or fixed-term polynomial regressions.  The Gradient Descent Curve Fits were done with a handwritten Least Squares Gradient Descent algorithm fitting a chemical equation to the data.  All plots created with Plots.jl.

elements.text:
In order from left: Reagent Product Plot, Reagent Polynomial Regression, Product Polynomial Regression, Reagent Gradient Descent Curve Fit, Product Gradient Descent Curve Fit

The Polynomial Regressions were done with MLJ.jl, which I extended to allow arbitrary-term polynomial regressions rather than only linear or fixed-term polynomial regressions.  The Gradient Descent Curve Fits were done with a handwritten Least Squares Gradient Descent algorithm fitting a chemical equation to the data.  All plots created with Plots.jl.

messages.text: My first proper contribution to Julia. A code generator from json samples. Check it out: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-quicktype-generate-json3-structs-from-json-samples-wip/52948>

attachments.title: [ANN] Quicktype -- generate JSON3 structs from json samples (WIP)
attachments.text: Quicktype is a neat program that infers schemas from json samples and generates code in various different languages to read the json into native objects. I hacked together basic support for Julia in Quicktype. It should work for basic json. Enums, Unions, Nullables and escaping strings do not work properly yet. If your json doesn’t have these and the keys in your dictionaries do not contain the dollar sign, you can probably already use it. Here is an example of what it does. Clone the repo and...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: [ANN] Quicktype -- generate JSON3 structs from json samples (WIP)

messages.text:
Hi, is there a comparison function in Julia, that would compare `NaN` values correctly and also compare floats using `≈` ?
Somethich which would return true for
`functionImLookingFor([(78/9-64/9), NaN], [14/9, NaN])` , because `isequal` works well with NaN, but not for comparing floats, and `≈`  does not work well with `NaN`s.

messages.text: A professor I know is teaching a probabilistic programming class using Julia this semester, and was wondering if anyone has recommendations for a concise “tour of Julia” for people who know how to program but need an overview of all of Julia’s programming constructs. Ideally it would be information-dense, high-coverage, and relatively self-contained. Is there anything like this?

elements.text: A professor I know is teaching a probabilistic programming class using Julia this semester, and was wondering if anyone has recommendations for a concise “tour of Julia” for people who know how to program but need an overview of all of Julia’s programming constructs. Ideally it would be information-dense, high-coverage, and relatively self-contained. Is there anything like this?

messages.text:
Hi there. I got twice in a row the BREAKING label after submitting a new version of a package. Despite it, it still merges automatically. CI is good on my package side and on the general registry side.
As there is no explanation for the label, I would like to know what it means in that case. Any idea?

elements.text:
Hi there. I got twice in a row the BREAKING label after submitting a new version of a package. Despite it, it still merges automatically. CI is good on my package side and on the general registry side.
As there is no explanation for the label, I would like to know what it means in that case. Any idea?

messages.text: If you go from 0.a.b to 0.(a+1).* you get the breaking label. Or if you go from a.b.* to (a+1).*....

elements.text: If you go from 0.a.b to 0.(a+1).* you get the breaking label. Or if you go from a.b.* to (a+1).*....
